columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to assess the rights offerings.

The **right offering** is a public offering of shares in which existing shareholders are initially given securities. There is no additional stock issued in a rights issue, lowering a present company's ownership proportion as long as the existing shareholder exercises all of his rights to maintain an equal proportion shareholding by subscribing to new share financings at or below market rates.

Let us first identify the given amounts in the problem: 


| | Amount$\hspace{5pt}$| 
|:--|--:| 
|Rights offer | $35 million|
|Nonrefundable reviewing fee | $5,000.00| 
|Stock price  |$53.00 |
|Number of shares outstanding  |3.9 million |

Let us start by determining the highest possible stock subscription price. The **subscription price** is the fixed price that investors may subscribe to in a public rights offering. This is usually less than the stock's current market price.

The firm can do this equity issue, and a subscriber, a prospective investor, purchases the stocks.



**The firm's maximum subscription price is the price per share that subscribers in the offering will pay at the beginning.** The firm has the option of lowering its subscription price; the **minimum price might be less than $53.00 and more than $0**. If the firm decreases its subscription price, it will need to issue additional stocks.

## B. 

Next, we will figure out how many stocks will be sold and how many rights will be required to purchase one share. 

The entire amount of rights offered to be acquired for the new journal is divided by the price per share to establish the firm's share that must be sold. The following formula is used to calculate this:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of shares }&=\dfrac{\text{Amount of rights offer}}{\text{Share price}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$35 million}}{\text{\$47.00}}\\[10pt]
&={\textbf{744,681 stocks}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**If the subscription price is set at $47.00 per share, the company needs to sell 744,681 stocks.**

Then, let us determine the number of rights need to buy a share of stock. This is computed as follows: 



$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of rights }&=\dfrac{\text{Shares outstanding}}{\text{New shares}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{3.9 million }}{\text{744,681}}\\[10pt]
&={\textbf{5.24}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The number of rights required to buy stocks is 5.24 rights.**

## C. 

After that, we will determine the ex-rights price by calculating the stock's market value. The current stock price is multiplied by the number of rights required to purchase a stock. 

However, an investor may exercise the rights at the firm's subscription price; therefore, we will multiply the subscription price by the result of the first process. Here is an illustration of what this calculation would look like to help understand it better:


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{New market price}&={\text{(Rights needed $\times$ Share price) + Subscription price}}\\[5pt]
&={\text{(5.24 $\times$ \$53.00) + \$47.00}}\\[5pt]
&={\textbf{\$324.72}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The total cost of the shareholder can exercise the rights amounts to $324.72**

Let us calculate the ex-rights price by dividing the new market price by the number of ex-rights stocks. 

When an investor buys 5.24 rights-on stocks, the investor may exercise the rights for additional $47.00, hence the ex-rights stocks are calculated by adding 1 to the rights-on. The following formula is used to calculate this:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Ex-rights price}&=\dfrac{\text{New market price }}{\text{ 1 + Rights-on}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$324.72}}{\text{ 1 + 5.24}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$324.72}}{\text{ 6.24}}\\[10pt]
&={\textbf{\$52.04}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The ex-rights price per share amounts to $52.04.**

We can now determine the value of a right by subtracting the market price per share by the ex-right price per share we have computed from step 8. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Value of the right}&={\text{Market value per share - Ex-right price per share}}\\[5pt]
&={\text{\$53.00 - \$52.04}}\\[5pt]
&={\textbf{\$0.96}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The value of one right amounts to $0.96.**

## D. 

Investors are offered to acquire additional securities in the firm through a rights offering. This allows investors the option to acquire securities at a lower specified price period. 

However, if investors do not purchase additional stocks, this will not affect current investors since the investor has proportionate rights on each share prior to the new rights offering.

So, with 1,000 shares, the stock price will certainly decline, but this comes with a set of rights. The following formula is used to calculate the share price decline:


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Amount of shares}&={\text{Number of shares  $\times$ Ex-rights price}}\\[5pt]
&={\text{1,000 shares $\times$ \$52.04}}\\[5pt]
&={\textbf{\$52,040.00}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The total amount of stock is $52,040.00.**

Then, we need to also determine the number of rights. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Amount of shares}&={\text{Number of shares  $\times$ Value of one right}}\\[5pt]
&={\text{1,000 shares $\times$ \$0.96}}\\[5pt]
&={\textbf{\$960.00}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The total amount of rights is $960.00.**

Finally, after the rights offer, the value of the portfolio of the shareholder will be equal to the total of amount of stocks and rights, which is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Value of the portfolio}&={\text{Amount of shares + Amount of rights}}\\[5pt]
&={\text{\$52,040.00 - \$960.00}}\\[5pt]
&={\textbf{\$53,000.00}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The value of the shareholder portfolio will still equal the current market price of $53,000.00.**
